definition: Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
tight (closely sealed)/stern/strict/rigorous/severe/father
surname Yan
to go and return/to return/to resume/to return to a normal or original state/to repeat/again/to recover/to restore/to turn over/to reply/to answer/to reply to a letter/to retaliate/to carry out
to repeat/to double/to overlap/complex (not simple)/compound/composite/double/diplo-/duplicate/overlapping/to duplicate
variant of 復|复[fu4]/to reply to a letter

sentences.english: Yan Fu was one of the representative figures of the reform idea.
sentences.chinese: 严复是维新思想的代表人物之一。

sentences.english: The word Liberty in Yan Fu's articles has different meanings.
sentences.chinese: 在严复的文章中，自由一词有多层涵义，应区别对待。

sentences.english: The object of this thesis is to investigate the political philosophy of Yan Fu.
sentences.chinese: 本文考察的对象是严复的政治哲学思想。

sentences.english: My thesis will analyse the economic ideas of YanFu.
sentences.chinese: 本论文试对严复的经济思想加以阐述与分析。

definition: Lin Shu (1852-1924), writer and influential translator and adaptor of vast swathes of Western literature into Classical Chinese
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
the theory of evolution (early translation, since replaced by 進化論|进化论)
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Ku Hung-ming or Gu Hongming (1857-1928), Malaysian man of letters, highly regarded for his literary works written mostly in English, and known for his monarchist views
courtesy name of Lin Shu 林紓|林纾[Lin2 Shu1]
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Liu Shipei (1884-1919), Chinese anarchist and revolutionary activist
Western learning (intellectual movement in the late Qing)/also called 洋務運動|洋务运动
Huang Zunxian (1848-1905), Qing dynasty poet and diplomat, author of A Record of Japan 日本國誌|日本国志[Ri4 ben3 Guo2 zhi4], an extended analysis of Meiji Japan
Liang Shuming (1893-1988), modern philosopher and teacher in the neo-Confucian tradition
Zhang Zhidong (1837-1909), prominent politician in late Qing
William A.P. Martin (1827-1916), American missionary who lived 62 years in China between 1850 and 1916, and helped found many Chinese colleges, first president of Peking University
Wei Yuan (1794-1857), Qing dynasty thinker, historian and scholar
